Jet parameters for a diverse sample of jet-launching post-AGB
binaries
Dylan Bollen,1,2,3‚òÖ Devika Kamath,2,3 Hans Van Winckel,1 Orsola De Marco2,3
and Mark Wardle2,3
1 Institute   of Astronomy, KU Leuven, Celestƒ≥nenlaan 200D, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium
2 Department     of Physics & Astronomy, Macquarie University, Sydney, NSW 2109, Australia
arXiv:2101.01967v1 [astro-ph.SR] 6 Jan 2021
3 Astronomy,    Astrophysics and Astrophotonics Research Centre, Macquarie University, Sydney, NSW 2109, Australia
Accepted XXX. Received YYY; in original form ZZZ
ABSTRACT
Jets are a commonly observed phenomenon in post-asymptotic giant branch (post-AGB)
binaries. Due to the orbital motion of the binary, the jet causes variable absorption in the Balmer
profiles. In previous work, we have developed spatio-kinematic and radiative transfer models to
reproduce the observed Balmer line variability and derive the spatio-kinematic structure of the
jet and its mass-loss rate. Here, we apply our jet model to five post-AGB binaries with distinct
Hùõº line variability and diverse orbital properties. Our models fit the Hùõº line variations very
well. We estimate jet mass-loss rates between 10‚àí8 M yr‚àí1 and 10‚àí4 M yr‚àí1 , from which
we deduce accretion rates onto the companion between 10‚àí7 M yr‚àí1 and 10‚àí3 M yr‚àí1 . These
accretion rates are somewhat higher than can be comfortably explained with reasonable sources
of accretion, but we argue that the circumbinary disc in these systems is most-likely the source
feeding the accretion, although accretion from the post-AGB star cannot be ruled out. The
diversity of the variability in the five objects is due to their wide ejection cones combined with
a range of viewing angles, rather than inherent differences between the objects. The nature of
the observations does not let us easily distinguish which jet launching model (stellar jet, disc
wind, or X-wind) should be favoured. In conclusion, we show that our jet model includes the
physical parameters to successfully reproduce the Hùõº line variations and retrieve the structure
and mass-loss rates of the jet for all five objects that are representative of the diverse sample
of Galactic post-AGB binaries.
Key words: Stars: AGB and post-AGB ‚Äì Stars: binaries: spectroscopic ‚Äì Stars: circumstellar
matter ‚Äì Stars: mass-loss ‚Äì Stars: jets ‚Äì Physical data and processes: Accretion, accretion discs
